text: well this gives you a taste of typhoon
koppu Orlando as they call it here in
the Philippines I've only been out of
doors for a few minutes I'm already
soaked to the skin I've come to this
village
Rahzel which is in the eastern side of
the island of luzon which is the hardest
hit by the typhoon as it came ashore in
the early hours now just looking around
you can see the twin problems that local
people face strong gusts to win doing a
fair bit of damage as we came here from
the capital Manila we passed quite a few
fallen trees but then what I'm feeling
in every second the rain the intensity
of it the sheer quantity that's what the
authorities are really worried about
because of the kind of flooding you can
see building up here in fact it's risen
a couple of inches just while we've been
here the real problem is that the
typhoon is losing a bit of you slowly
it's got mile or two every hour that
means that this extraordinary downpour
keeps hitting the same areas like this
one hour after hour the real danger with
this typhoon is not so much the wind but
the rain more than a meter of rainfall
forecast over just a couple of days and
that to put it into perspective is
around about double what they get in
London in an entire year
now that brings with it of course the
risk of flooding but perhaps more deadly
particularly in these mountainous areas
landslides
and this is what they're worried about
you can see where this huge metre wide
crack has developed in the earth as the
soil has become saturated with water you
come a bit further along and you can see
where the hillside has actually slipped
away tens if not hundreds of tons worth
of earth slipping down the hillside and
in the past in the Philippines
landslides have been deadly hundreds of
people killed particularly after heavy
rainfall and what they're worried about
here is you can see that small hamlet in
the distance seventy families live there
two hundred and fifty people they've had
to be evacuated because they're worried
that the whole side of this mountain
could slip down if it continues to rain
as people think it will do in the coming
days and those families have been
brought here to this makeshift
evacuation center in this local school
most of the people here are worried that
they won't even be able to return to
their homes such is the danger of land
slips they're worried about their
livelihoods most of them here are rice
farmers and tobacco growers across Luzon
province in the northern Philippines
more than 10,000 people have had to flee
their home some are under water because
of heavy flooding and this storm it's
far from over
we've still got three to four more days
of heavy rain forecast
